thoughts.summary: Summarizing the thesis methods and results
thoughts.content: I need to summarize the methods and results from the "HOMOLOGICAL FUNCTORS WITH COEFFICIENTS" thesis, making sure to cover all key points accurately. Since E-Jay uploaded their own thesis, I'll ensure it's precise without flattery, sticking strictly to essentials. I'll also provide the proper citations as required.

I’m trying to figure out the right citation approach for the thesis. The instructions seem conflicting: which to follow, line ranges or the minimal citation with the file ID? After reviewing, I think I should focus on including both citations and line ranges, as the guidelines seem to suggest that's what’s required. Now, I’ll pull up more of the thesis.

I need to look for connections to algebraic topology, chain complexes, spectra, algebraic K-theory, C*-algebras, and several category types. The table of contents includes related chapters, and I’ll need to search for specific theorems like 4.4.5 and 4.4.6. Let’s proceed with getting the relevant information.

content.text: {"queries": ["Summarize the methods and results of the thesis, and examine its connection to various branches of mathematics.", "universal coefficient sequence Theorems 4.4.5 and 4.4.6 NG E-Jay thesis", "definition of quasi-functor with coefficients NG thesis Definition 4.4", "multiplication by a column-finite matrix ϒ_N NG thesis Chapter 3", "Topological K-theory of C*-algebras with coefficients chapter 8 NG thesis"]}

thoughts.content: I need to gather more details about the thesis, particularly the definitions of homological functors with coefficients, as well as the universal coefficient sequence and colimit methods. Also, the OCR has produced unusual terms like "ning category," which might be a misread of "triangulated category" or perhaps something else entirely. I’ll dive into the introduction and summary for clarity.

[L82] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory

[L84] an extend the notion of a homologial funtor to more general ategories. The usual homotopy funtors

[L87] thesis.
[L88] In this thesis, we provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied to many

[L90] prelude to investigating funtors with oeÆients in abelian groups. The rationale for doing so is beause

[L173] CHAPTER 1. INTRODUCTION 1
[L174] Chapter 1
[L175] Introdution
[L176] 1.1 Goal of the thesis
[L177] If C is a triangulated ategory, a homologial funtor K : C ! A is a funtor whose target ategory
[L178] is an abelian ategory and whih sends distinguished triangles to long exat sequenes of A-ob jets. For
[L179] the de nition and properties of triangulated ategories, see either Verdier's lassial treatment [56℄ or
[L180] Neeman's modern aount [39℄.
[L181] Many funtors that give rise to long exat sequenes at on ategories that are not triangulated, for
[L182] example, the usual homotopy funtors on the ategory of pointed topologial spaes, the K-theory
[L183] funtors, and redued homology funtors on the ategory of pointed CW-omplexes. Hene, we should
[L184] extend the notion of a homologial funtor to inlude all these examples.
[L185] Given a homologial funtor K, the funtor K with oeÆients in an abelian group is often onstruted in
[L186] order to perform more omputations or derive new results. Some appliations of funtors with oeÆients
[L187] are provided in setion 1.2.
[L188] The goal of this thesis is to provide a framework for de ning funtors with oeÆients that an be applied
[L189] to many examples. There are two reasons for undertaking this pro jet:
[L190] 1. We an use the ommon framework to gain a better understanding of a wide range of homologial
[L191] funtors.
[L192] 2. In situations where no satisfatory de nition of funtors with oeÆients has been disovered, our
[L193] framework might suggest a possible approah.
[L194] 1.2 Some appliations of homologial funtors with oeÆients
[L195] In this setion, we list some appliations of homologial funtors with oeÆients to illustrate the usefulness of studying suh funtors.
[L196] 1.2.1 Real and omplex topologial K-theory with oeÆients
[L197] A reent paper by Berrik & Matthey [6℄ uses real topologial K-theory of C-algebras to onstrut a
[L198] strongly torsion generated group with spei ed abelian groups as its integral homology groups up to
[L199] dimension  ve.
[L200] This work is a ontinuation of the pro jet started by the same authors in [5℄, given as follows: Given n
[L201] abelian groups A; A2; A3; :::; An, onstrut a strongly torsion generated group S having, up to isomorphism, A as its entre and Aq as its q
[L202] th integral homology group Hq (S) for 2  q  n. In [5℄, reasons
[L203] are laid out for initiating this pro jet, and [5℄ realizes the pro jet for n = 3 using omplex topologial

[L205] CHAPTER 1. INTRODUCTION 2
[L206] K-theory of C-algebras. In partiular, the onstrution involves using a C-algebra whose omplex
[L207] topologial K-theory is A in even dimensions and 0 in odd dimensions, in other words, a C-algebra
[L208] whose omplex topologial K-theory is given by KUtop
[L209]  (C ; A), where C denotes the base  eld of omplex
[L210] numbers, and KUtop
[L211]  (; A) denotes omplex topologial K-theory with oeÆients in A.
[L212] In [6℄, it is shown that if abelian groups A; B ; C; D; E are spei ed, one an always onstrut a strongly
[L213] torsion generated group S whose entre is isomorphi to A and whose higher integral homology up to
[L214] dimension  ve is given by H2(S) = B, H3(S) = C, H4(S) = D, H5(S) = E. The onstrution involves
[L215] using a real C-algebra EA whose real topologial K-theory is losely related to A (see setion 3 of [6℄).
[L216] In this thesis, we de ne real topologial K-theory with oeÆients in any olumn- nite matrix of nonnegative integers. It turns out that the real topologial K-theory of EA is the same as the real topologial
[L217] K-theory (modulo some dimension shift) of R with oeÆients in N, where N is the matrix orresponding
[L218] to any arbitrarily hosen nonnegative presentation of A (see setion 8.3 of this thesis).
[L219] This example forms the prototype for de ning and studying funtors with oeÆients in a olumn- nite
[L220] matrix of nonnegative integers.
[L221] 1.2.2 Algebrai K-theory with oeÆients
[L222] Algebrai K-theory with mod p oeÆients, that is, oeÆients in an abelian group Z=pZ, was  rst

thoughts.summary: Summarizing methods, results, and key connections
thoughts.content: I’m ready to summarize the methods, results, and connections, but I need to review Chapter 4 for specific theorems and clarifications on "quasi-functors" and "coning" (likely "cofibration"). The symbols and sequences discussed suggest some complex relationships, so I'll carefully check references and line citations. Also, I’ll include algebraic and topological examples.

I need to explain natural transformations related to "multiplication by a matrix" and how these apply to restricted power functors. I'll also review how this ties into different mathematical areas like algebraic topology, homological algebra, category theory, K-theory, and C*-algebras. This involves understandable group theory and ring theory connections as well.

Instead of listing specific propositions like 5.2.1, I’ll summarize that these results recover standard homology with coefficients and equivalences for \(H(A \otimes G)\) when \(A\) is flat, along with universal coefficient exact sequences. I’ll also consider restricted product properties, but might leave that out for simplicity. Citations from lines 81-166 will be included.

parts:
# What the thesis does—methods in one through-line

The thesis builds a general, presentation-independent way to attach “coefficients” to any homological functor \(K\) on a broad class of categories that have mapping cones (called **coning categories**) or dually, mapping path objects (called **ning categories**). The key technical move is to replace ad-hoc tensoring with an abelian group \(G\) by a **categorical calculus of column-finite integer matrices** acting on **restricted products** (filtered colimits of finite products). Given a presentation \(\mathbb Z[J]\xrightarrow{Q(\phi)}\mathbb Z[I]\twoheadrightarrow G\), let \(N\) be its column-finite matrix. One then forms a canonical map \(\Upsilon_N\) between restricted powers (or coproducts) and defines the *object with \(N\)-coefficients* by taking a mapping cone (or mapping path) of \(\Upsilon_N\). Applying \(K\) to this cone/path yields the **value of \(K\) with coefficients**, denoted \(K^m(-;N)\). Because mapping cones/paths are not unique on the nose, the construction is a **quasi-functor**, with arrows well-defined up to a strong quasi-naturality condition; when extra monoidal structure is present the quasi-functor upgrades to a genuine homological functor. fileciteturn8file2L17-L29 fileciteturn10file1L17-L25 fileciteturn6file4L8-L26 fileciteturn7file1L94-L111

Two bits of infrastructure make this work. First, **restricted products** are used because many target functors (e.g., topological \(K\)-theory on \(C^*\)-algebras) are well behaved for finite products and filtered colimits but *not* for arbitrary coproducts; restricted products capture exactly that regime. Second, the thesis develops the **“multiplication by a matrix”** formalism in categories with restricted products or with coproducts, including composition control \(\Upsilon_{MN}=\Upsilon_M\Upsilon_N\) under mild axioms RP3–RP5. fileciteturn8file2L27-L34 fileciteturn7file3L112-L120 fileciteturn7file1L77-L85 fileciteturn4file1L1-L3

Finally, the thesis situates the whole story in a very general categorical environment: triangulated categories and homotopy categories of model categories give canonical examples of coning/ning categories; the “quasi-” language formalizes the fact mapping cones/paths are only unique up to non-unique isomorphism. fileciteturn11file2L47-L56 fileciteturn11file2L3-L13 fileciteturn6file1L4-L13

# Core results

The central theorems are **universal coefficient short exact sequences (UCT)**. For a coning category with restricted products and a column-finite \(N\) representing \(G=\mathrm{coker}(\mathbb Z[J]\to \mathbb Z[I])\), the thesis proves
\[
G\otimes K^m(C) \longrightarrow K^m(C;N) \longrightarrow \mathrm{Tor}(G,K^{m+1}(C))
\]
with both arrows strongly quasi-natural in \(C\) (and natural when the coning structure is functorially generated). Dually, for ning categories there is
\[
G\otimes K^{m+1}(C) \longrightarrow K^{m+1}(C;N) \longrightarrow \mathrm{Tor}(G,K^{m}(C)).
\]
These sequences need not split in general, exactly mirroring classical UCT phenomena. fileciteturn6file2L2-L17 fileciteturn6file0L102-L110 fileciteturn6file3L36-L52

A second pillar is **presentation independence**: once the matrix composition law \(\Upsilon_{MN}=\Upsilon_M\Upsilon_N\) is established, the value \(K^m(C;N)\) depends only on the *group* \(G\) presented by \(N\), not the choice of presentation, allowing one to write \(K^m(C;G)\). This is proved first for nonnegative presentations, then for arbitrary presentations under mild hypotheses. fileciteturn4file1L1-L3 fileciteturn8file1L20-L25

Third, when the ambient category is **symmetric monoidal** (tensor triangulated will do), the construction becomes a genuine homological functor \(K^m(-;G)\) for any abelian \(G\), obtained by tensoring a fixed cone object with inputs. In this case functoriality and long exact sequences are immediate from the monoidal axioms. fileciteturn10file3L1-L9 fileciteturn10file3L20-L33

# Worked examples showing the scope

For **homotopy groups with coefficients**, the thesis defines \(\pi_k(X;G)\) in the homotopy category of compactly generated spaces by taking mapping paths of the matrix map \(\Upsilon_N\) and shows the expected short exact sequence
\[
G\otimes \pi_k(X)\to \pi_k(X;G)\to \mathrm{Tor}\bigl(G,\pi_{k-1}(X)\bigr),
\]
with naturality in \(X\) and strong quasi-naturality in \(G\). This agrees with classical constructions via Peterson spaces/Moore spaces and clarifies when such UCT sequences do or do not split. fileciteturn9file1L6-L17 fileciteturn9file1L33-L37 fileciteturn6file3L36-L52

For **reduced homology theories**, the matrix-cone approach recovers the standard \(H_*(X;G)\) and, at the spectrum level, identifies “\(G\)-coefficients” with smashing by a **Moore spectrum** \(M(G)\): \(h_n(X;G)=\pi_n(X\wedge (M(G)\wedge E))\) for the spectrum \(E\) representing the homology theory \(h\). This gives a clean spectrum-theoretic picture of coefficients. fileciteturn10file0L26-L33 fileciteturn9file4L24-L33

For **algebraic \(K\)-theory of nonunital rings (rngs)**, coefficients are defined by \(K_n(A;N):=K_n(C_A{}_{\Upsilon_N})\), and one gets a long exact sequence and a UCT short exact sequence \(G\otimes K_n(A)\to K_n(A;N)\to \mathrm{Tor}(G,K_{n-1}(A))\), natural in \(A\). The construction also aligns with the homotopy-theoretic “\(K(\text{–};G)\)” seen in the literature when \(G\) is countable. fileciteturn10file4L14-L35 fileciteturn8file4L44-L51

For **topological \(K\)-theory of \(C^*\)-algebras**, the thesis uses the **bootstrap category** (Boot) and the **Künneth Theorem for tensor products (KTP)** to pin down coefficients for complex and real \(C^*\)-algebras. In particular, the matrix-cone construction matches the standard definition \(KU_n(A;G)=KU_n(A\otimes \mathcal T(G))\) for a suitable \(C^*\)-algebra \(\mathcal T(G)\) with \(KU_*(\mathcal T(G))=(G,0)\), and the mapping-cone presentation is shown equivalent in this setting. fileciteturn8file4L47-L55 fileciteturn8file4L56-L58 fileciteturn8file4L34-L46

# How it connects across mathematics

**Category theory & homological algebra.** The coning/ning axioms abstract the part of triangulated/model category structure actually used by homological functors, without needing rotation/octahedra. The UCTs derived are the categorical avatars of classical UCT/Künneth short exact sequences, with the same non-splitting pathologies when \(G\) has torsion in certain congruence classes. The “matrix calculus” furnishes a presentation-level replacement for derived tensor, and the independence of presentation parallels the passage from projective resolutions to derived functors. fileciteturn11file2L47-L53 fileciteturn6file3L36-L52

**Algebraic topology.** Moore/Peterson spaces and Moore spectra drop out naturally from the matrix-cone construction, tying homotopy and homology with coefficients to explicit cones/paths of maps between wedges/products—then to smashing with \(M(G)\) in spectra. The approach works uniformly for finitely generated and (in homotopy) countable coefficients. fileciteturn9file3L37-L46 fileciteturn9file4L12-L21 fileciteturn9file2L1-L8

**\(K\)-theory (algebraic and topological).** The same mechanism furnishes \(K(\text{–};G)\) for nonunital rings and \(KU(\text{–};G)\) for \(C^*\)-algebras, matching classical definitions and recovering UCTs in both settings. The restricted-product formalism is especially natural for operator algebras, where “complete direct sums” are the categorical form of restricted products. fileciteturn10file4L26-L35 fileciteturn8file4L47-L55 fileciteturn7file3L113-L120

**Model categories & triangulated/symmetric monoidal contexts.** Because many natural habitats (stable homotopy category, derived categories, homotopy categories of model categories) are coning/ning and often symmetric monoidal, the construction scales: in tensor triangulated settings one gets honest functors \(K^m(-;G)\) for all \(G\), not just quasi-functors tied to a chosen presentation. fileciteturn11file0L4-L10 fileciteturn10file2L10-L17

# Assessment and forward look

Methodologically, the thesis extracts the minimal categorical scaffolding needed to attach coefficients and to prove UCTs, and it shows that “coefficients = mapping cone of a matrix map” is a unifying principle spanning homology, homotopy, and both flavors of \(K\)-theory. Where cones/paths are only weakly functorial one pays a quasi-naturality tax; introducing symmetric monoidal structure pays that tax in full and yields true functors. The reliance on restricted products and cardinality bounds (RP1/RP2/RP3–RP5) is a feature, not a bug—it’s tuned to the exact continuity properties real functors have in practice—but it does mean the cleanest functorial statements arrive in monoidal or functorially generated contexts. Non-splitting of UCTs is correctly preserved (e.g., certain mod-\(l\) cases), aligning with classical obstructions. fileciteturn7file1L77-L85 fileciteturn6file3L36-L52

For extensions, the most natural modern recast is in **stable \(\infty\)-categories**, where mapping cones are unique up to contractible choice; one should then expect the quasi-functor issues to disappear and the matrix-cone recipe to compare directly to derived tensoring with **module spectra** modeling \(G\). The thesis’ spectrum-level descriptions and monoidal upgrade theorems suggest this path is viable, and the \(C^*\)-algebra work hints at further noncommutative directions (e.g., KK-theoretic coefficients) that fit the same template. (Those forward-looking remarks are my synthesis; the core results above are from the thesis.)

---

If you’d like, I can extract a one-page crib of the main definitions (restricted product, \(\Upsilon_N\), coning/ning category, quasi-functor/strong quasi-naturality) with a minimal diagram chase that shows exactly where each UCT arrow comes from.
Examine how the methods of the thesis can be made more robust and explore ways to extend these results, and provide higher order constructions and generalizations.

**Enhancing thesis methods**

I’m mapping out ways to strengthen thesis sections by expanding definitions, integrating advanced category theory, and using derived functors and spectral sequences to generalize results.

**Expanding methods**

Integrating advanced algebraic structures like iterated coefficients, matrix calculus, and coefficient parametric adjunction to generalize and enrich higher-order constructions in the thesis.

**Enhancing thesis robustness**

I’m suggesting integrating advanced concepts like stable ∞-categories, derivators, and spectral sequences. Also, proposing generalizations to multi-coefficient towers and derived tensor methods to address failure modes.

**Proposing robustification**

I’m suggesting using stable ∞-categories to ensure functoriality, embedding matrix calculus via finite-product-preserving functors, and defining coefficient objects for a more robust framework.

**Proposing advancement**

I’m mapping out the use of stable derivators for functorial cones, extending matrix calculus to Pro/Ind-completions, and revisiting restricted product frameworks to ensure comprehensive enhancement.

**Crafting and detailing**

I’m piecing together specific theorems and proofs for each proposal. This involves including file citations, maintaining clarity, and steering clear of unnecessary details, especially personal ones.

Below I’ll do three things:

1) **Tighten the foundations** (make the constructions more robust, remove ad‑hoc choices, and isolate minimal hypotheses).  
2) **Extend “coefficients” beyond abelian groups** (to chain complexes, spectra, twists, parametrized families, bivariant settings).  
3) **Propose higher‑order/derived constructions** (spectral sequences, obstruction classes, and secondary/higher UCT phenomena).

Where I lean on specifics from the thesis, I cite them so you can map proposals to the precise technical seams in the document.

---

## 1) Making the methods more robust

### 1.1. Replace quasi‑functoriality by honest functoriality via stable settings
The thesis works with **coning/ning categories** in which mapping cones/paths exist but are only determined *up to non‑unique isomorphism*; this is exactly why coefficients first appear as *quasi‑functors* with strong quasi‑naturality rather than genuine functors. The non‑canonicity is formalized in axiom **C4** and the definition of quasi‑functor/strong quasi‑natural transformation. fileciteturn13file16 fileciteturn12file5

**Upgrade:** Move to any **presentable stable \(\infty\)-category** (or a stable model where cones are functorial up to *contractible* choice). In this context, mapping cones are functorial, and the quasi‑functor tax disappears. This is already hinted at inside the thesis’ monoidal upgrade: when the ambient category is **symmetric monoidal**, the “with‑coefficients” assignment is an *honest homological functor* \(X\mapsto K(C_{\Upsilon_N} \otimes X)\). The argument is that tensoring preserves coning/ning sequences and hence the long exact sequences, turning the recipe into a strict homological functor. fileciteturn12file7

**Deliverable:** Restate all constructions in a stable \(\infty\)-categorical envelope of your favorite examples (derived categories, stable homotopy, KK‑contexts). The proofs that use “choose a cone” become proofs that use universal properties, removing dependence on C4-choices. fileciteturn13file16

---

### 1.2. Abstract the “matrix calculus” via co/ends instead of indices
The thesis implements “multiplication by a (column‑finite) matrix” as a natural map
\[
\Upsilon_N:\ \prod\nolimits^{\mathrm{res}}_{J} M C\ \longrightarrow\ \prod\nolimits^{\mathrm{res}}_{I} M C,
\]
with composition \(\Upsilon_{MN}=\Upsilon_M\Upsilon_N\) verified under RP3–RP5. fileciteturn13file5 fileciteturn13file13 fileciteturn13file17

**Robustification:** Recast this as **co/end calculus** for additive presheaves: encode “column‑finite matrices” as morphisms in the free additive completion of a discrete category, and define \(\Upsilon\) as a **coend** acting on a restricted‑product monad. This achieves:
- functorial composition without chasing indices (it becomes associativity of co/ends);
- a clean path to general coefficient *objects* (not just groups) as modules for the monad.

Technically, the RP‑axioms are ensuring that \(M\) commutes with restricted products and that the enhanced “summation” maps behave coherently (RP3–RP5). A co/end packaging lets you swap those axioms for “presentability + exactness of filtered colimits + preservation of (co)limits by \(M\)”, which are easier to check in stable/presentable environments. fileciteturn13file5 fileciteturn13file2

---

### 1.3. Replace “restricted product” hypotheses by presentability/compact generation
Restricted products are used because many target functors preserve finite products and filtered colimits but not arbitrary coproducts. The thesis codifies this with RP1–RP5 and shows how they interact with \(M\). fileciteturn12file12 fileciteturn13file11

**Upgrade:** Work in **compactly generated presentable** stable settings: require \(M\) to preserve \(\kappa\)-filtered colimits and finite products; then define “restricted product” as the **right Kan extension** of finite products along the inclusion of finite sets. This reduces size‑bookkeeping while keeping the exactness needed for \(\Upsilon\)-composition and the UCT proofs. Where the thesis warns that \(M^2\not\simeq M\) can break naive identifications (e.g., loops vs double loops), keep those distinctions explicit rather than identifying maps like \(r^J_{Q^I}\) with \(r^J\) unless there is a *given* \(M^2\simeq M\). fileciteturn13file14

---

## 2) Extending what “coefficients” can mean

The thesis proves **UCT short exact sequences** for abelian‑group coefficients and shows presentation‑independence (matrix presentations give the same result). fileciteturn12file3 fileciteturn12file9

### 2.1. Derived coefficients: chain complexes and spectra
**Generalization:** Allow the coefficient to be a **chain complex \(C\)** (or better, a **spectrum \(E\)**). In a symmetric monoidal stable environment, define
\[
K_*(-;C)\ :=\ K_*\bigl(\,\mathsf{Moore}(C)\otimes -\,\bigr),\qquad
K_*(-;E)\ :=\ K_*\bigl(E\otimes -\bigr),
\]
where \(\mathsf{Moore}(C)\) is the Moore object (or \(H\!C\) if you have Eilenberg–MacLane objects). This directly recovers the thesis’ spectrum‑level viewpoint for ordinary homology (smashing with a Moore spectrum \(M(G)\)), but now for *any* derived coefficient. fileciteturn12file7

**Payoff:** You obtain a **universal‑coefficient spectral sequence (UCSS)** rather than a mere short exact sequence:
\[
E^2_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\bigl(H_q(C),\,K_*(X)\bigr)
\ \ \Rightarrow\ \ K_{p+q}(X;C),
\]
under standard boundedness/flatness hypotheses (the thesis already proves the \(p\in\{0,1\}\) edge as a short exact UCT when \(C=G[0]\)). The proof is just the Künneth spectral sequence for \(\otimes\) together with the thesis’ observation that in monoidal settings the coefficient functor is strictly homological. fileciteturn12file7

> **Remark:** For cohomological variants, replace Tor by Ext and reverse arrows as usual.

---

### 2.2. Twisted and parametrized coefficients
**Twists:** In a symmetric monoidal setting, let \(\mathrm{Pic}(\mathcal C)\) be the Picard \(\infty\)-groupoid of invertible objects. A *twist* \(\tau\) is a map \(X\to B\,\mathrm{Pic}(\mathcal C)\) (or a local system of invertibles). Define
\[
K_*(X;G,\tau)\ :=\ K_*\bigl( X\otimes M(G) \otimes L_\tau\bigr),
\]
with \(L_\tau\) the associated line object. The thesis’ C\(^*\)-examples already force monoidal exactness and restricted sums, so this generalization fits naturally there and recovers twisted topological \(K\)‑theories (now with \(G\)-coefficients). fileciteturn12file17

**Parametrized families of presentations:** Instead of a single matrix \(N\), allow a *bundle* of matrices over a base \(B\) (a functor from \(\Pi_1(B)\) into the matrix category). The restricted product and cone construction then run fiberwise and glue, yielding local‑coefficient systems \(G_b\) and the expected UCT in families.

---

### 2.3. Bivariant and equivariant extensions
**Bivariant:** If \(K\) is represented in a monoidal stable category (as the thesis does for many examples), define a bivariant theory
\[
K_*(A\to B;\,G)\ :=\ K_*\Bigl(\,C_{\Upsilon_N}(A)\otimes B\,\Bigr),
\]
or in KK‑contexts as \(KK(A,\,\mathcal T(G)\otimes B)\). The matrix calculus still controls the coefficient object; the monoidal structure gives functoriality. (This is a natural extension of the thesis’ \(C^*\) setup where exactness and minimal tensor are carefully arranged.) fileciteturn12file17

**Equivariant:** If a group \(G_{\mathrm{act}}\) acts on the ambient category, coefficients refine to **Mackey‑style** families; the matrix \(N\) becomes a morphism in the equivariant additive envelope, giving \(K_*^{G_{\mathrm{act}}}(-;\mathcal N)\) and equivariant UCSS.

## 3) Higher‑order and derived constructions

### 3.1. From short exact UCT to towers and invariants
The thesis gives a short exact UCT
\[
G\otimes K_m(C)\ \longrightarrow\ K_m(C;G)\ \longrightarrow\ \mathrm{Tor}(G,K_{m-1}(C)),
\]
with strong quasi‑naturality and functoriality in monoidal cases. fileciteturn12file3 fileciteturn12file9

**Higher‑order generalization:** For a bounded‑below chain complex \(C\) of coefficients, filter \(C\) by its Postnikov tower. Exact couples then produce a **UCT/Künneth spectral sequence** whose \(E^2\) is Tor over \(\mathbb Z\) as above, and whose differentials detect the *extension class* that obstructs splitting of the short exact UCT when \(C\) is concentrated in degree \(0\). This makes precise (and computable) the non‑splitting phenomena already preserved by the thesis’ UCT. (Conceptually: the short exact UCT is the 2‑line truncation of this spectral sequence.)

---

### 3.2. Secondary and higher operations
The non‑splitting in UCT is governed by a class in \(\mathrm{Ext}^1\), and in “derived‑coefficient” settings, by higher \(\mathrm{Ext}\). Package these as **k‑invariants** of the coefficient object \(M(C)\) in the monoidal category. In homotopy‑theoretic cases this aligns with Toda brackets; in algebraic \(K\)‑theory of rings it relates to higher \(K\)‑groups of Moore objects (see the thesis’ identification of \(K_n(A;G)\) via the Moore/suspension machines). fileciteturn12file14

---

### 3.3. A 2‑(or \(\infty\))‑categorical “coefficient calculus”
Formalize the category **Mat**\(_{\mathrm{cf}}\) whose objects are sets and 1‑morphisms are column‑finite matrices, with composition by matrix product (proved to be compatible with \(\Upsilon\) under RP3–RP5). Then make your ambient category \( \mathcal C\) a **pseudo‑module** over Mat\(_{\mathrm{cf}}\) by sending a set \(I\) to the restricted power functor and a matrix \(N\) to \(\Upsilon_N\). The thesis already proves the key compatibility (\(\Upsilon_{MN}=\Upsilon_M\Upsilon_N\)) under RP‑axioms; encoding this as an action removes many diagram chases later on. fileciteturn13file17 fileciteturn13file2

Once this action is set up, a coefficient object *is* just the cone of the action of a presentation \(N\), and presentation‑independence becomes a **coherence statement** in this module action rather than a bespoke argument case‑by‑case (the thesis proves independence as Theorem 4.6.5/Remark 4.6.6). fileciteturn12file3

---

### 3.4. Robust “size” management and universes
The technical heart of the matrix calculus is ensuring arrows are defined on restricted powers of size \(<\kappa\), that \(M\) commutes with these, and that the various enhanced aggregation maps \(r\) satisfy RP1–RP5. The thesis spells out these properties and where they are used. fileciteturn12file12 fileciteturn13file11

**Upgrade:** Fix a Grothendieck universe \( \mathbb U\) and work in the presentable \( \mathbb U\)-stable category generated by your compact objects. Take \(M\) to be an accessible exact endofunctor that preserves \(\mathbb U\)-filtered colimits. Re‑prove RP1–RP5 abstractly from presentability + exactness rather than ad hoc. This shields the calculus from point‑set issues (e.g., the loop functor not satisfying \(M^2\simeq M\)), which the thesis notes explicitly cannot be assumed in general. fileciteturn13file14

## A. Setup and basic definitions (stable ∞‑categorical)

### A.0. Ambient data
- Let \(\mathcal C\) be a **presentable stable \(\infty\)-category** equipped with a **closed symmetric monoidal** structure \((\mathcal C,\otimes,\mathbb 1)\) that is exact in each variable and preserves colimits separately.
- Let \(\mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}\) denote the \(\infty\)-category of module spectra over \(H\mathbb Z\) (equivalently, the derived \(\infty\)-category \(D(\mathbb Z)\)).
- Fix a **baseline homology functor**
  \[
    K:\mathcal C \longrightarrow \mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}
  \]
  that is **exact** and **colimit‑preserving**. (This models the thesis’ “homological functor” \(K\). In many examples \(K\) is represented by a spectrum object and/or is lax monoidal; the monoidal upgrade in the thesis is the 1‑categorical shadow of this situation. fileciteturn12file2)

> **Consistency check with the thesis.** When \(\mathcal C\) is a symmetric monoidal coning/ning category in the sense of Ch. 7, the thesis shows that the “with‑coefficients” assignment is a **strict homological functor** (not just a quasi‑functor). That is exactly what the presentable symmetric monoidal hypothesis ensures for us. fileciteturn12file2

### A.1. Coefficient objects
- View an **abelian group** \(G\) as \(H\mathbb Z\)-module \(HG\).
- More generally, for a **chain complex** \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\cong \mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}\), write \(HC\) for the corresponding \(H\mathbb Z\)-module spectrum.

> **Definition (Derived coefficients).** For \(X\in\mathcal C\) and \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\),
\[
  K(X;C)\ :=\ K(X)\ \otimes_{H\mathbb Z}\ HC \ \in \ \mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z},\qquad
  K_n(X;C)\ :=\ \pi_n\bigl(K(X;C)\bigr).
\]
If \(G\) is an abelian group placed in degree \(0\) (so \(C=G[0]\)), this recovers the usual \(G\)-coefficients as defined in the thesis, and becomes a genuine homological functor in the symmetric monoidal setting. fileciteturn12file2

> **Compatibility with Moore objects (thesis).** For ordinary reduced homology on spaces, the thesis identifies “\(G\)-coefficients” with smashing by a **Moore spectrum** \(M(G)\): \(h_n(X;G)=\pi_n\bigl(X\wedge(M(G)\wedge E)\bigr)\). In our language this is \(K(X;G)\simeq K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z} HG\), and \(M(G)\) realizes \(HG\) in the relevant stable category. fileciteturn12file1 fileciteturn12file3

## B. Derived UCSS: statement

> **Theorem (Derived UCSS over \(\mathbb Z\)).**  
Fix \(X\in\mathcal C\) and \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\). There is a natural, right‑half‑plane spectral sequence
\[
E^2_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\!\bigl(H_q(C),\ K_*(X)\bigr)\ \Longrightarrow\ K_{p+q}(X;C),
\]
functorial in maps \(X\to X'\) and quasi‑isomorphisms \(C\to C'\). If either \(C\) is bounded below or \(K(X)\) is connective and bounded below, the spectral sequence is **strongly convergent**. The \(p=0,1\) edge recovers the thesis’ UCT short exact sequence when \(C=G[0]\) is concentrated in degree \(0\). fileciteturn12file14

*Remarks.*  
- Over a general commutative ring \(R\), replace \(H\mathbb Z\) and \(\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}\) by \(HR\) and \(\mathrm{Tor}^{R}\).  
- If \(C\) is flat (e.g. a complex of flat \(\mathbb Z\)-modules), the \(E^2\)-page degenerates to the thesis’ Künneth short exact sequence for chain complexes (your eq. (1‑6)). fileciteturn12file7

---

## C. Skeleton proof

The proof is a standard filtration/derived‑tensor argument in \(\mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}\), tailored to line up with the thesis’ monoidal upgrade and Moore‑object viewpoint.

**Step 1 — Express coefficients as derived tensor.**  
By definition \(K(X;C)=K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z}HC\). In the thesis’ monoidal settings this coincides with the “cone of a matrix map then apply \(K\)” construction, because tensoring by the fixed cone (or Moore) object turns quasi‑functors into honest homological functors. fileciteturn12file2 fileciteturn12file3

**Step 2 — Postnikov filtration of \(HC\).**  
In \(\mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}\) take the canonical Postnikov tower
\[
\cdots \to \tau_{\le q}HC \to \tau_{\le q+1}HC \to \cdots \to HC,
\]
with successive fibers \(\mathrm{fib}(\tau_{\le q}HC\to \tau_{\le q-1}HC)\simeq \Sigma^{q}H(H_q(C))\). (Here \(H(H_q(C))\) is the Eilenberg–Mac Lane \(H\mathbb Z\)-module of the abelian group \(H_q(C)\).)

**Step 3 — Filter \(K(X;C)\).**  
Tensor the tower with \(K(X)\): since \(\otimes_{H\mathbb Z}\) is exact and preserves colimits in each variable, we get a filtered object \(\{F_q\}\) with
\[
\mathrm{gr}_q\,K(X;C)\ \simeq\ K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z}\Sigma^q H(H_q(C))\ \simeq\ \Sigma^q\bigl(K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z} H(H_q(C))\bigr).
\]
This is the “Moore layer” description—the same mechanism by which the thesis identifies \(G\)-coefficients with smashing by \(M(G)\). fileciteturn12file1

**Step 4 — Exact couple and \(E^1\)-page.**  
Apply \(\pi_*\) to the filtered object to obtain an exact couple and a spectral sequence. The \(E^1\)-page is
\[
E^1_{p,q}\ \cong\ \pi_{p+q}\bigl(K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z}\Sigma^q H(H_q(C))\bigr)\ \cong\ \pi_p \bigl(K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z} H(H_q(C))\bigr).
\]
The \(d^1\) differentials come from the \(k\)-invariants of the Postnikov tower of \(HC\). Passing to \(E^2\) computes the **left‑derived functors** of \((-) \mapsto \pi_*(K(X)\otimes_{H\mathbb Z}H(-))\), which are precisely \(\mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}\) applied to \(H_q(C)\) and \(K_*(X)\). Thus
\[
E^2_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\!\bigl(H_q(C),\ K_*(X)\bigr).
\]

> This is the homotopical version of the classical Künneth story; for flat \(C\) you recover the thesis’ short exact Künneth/UCT line (Theorem 1.4.1) as the \(p\in\{0,1\}\) truncation. fileciteturn12file7

**Step 5 — Convergence and naturality.**  
If \(C\) is bounded below (or \(K(X)\) is connective and bounded below), the filtration is bounded on each total degree, yielding a first‑quadrant spectral sequence that **strongly converges** to \(\pi_*(K(X;C))=K_*(X;C)\). Naturality in \(X\) follows from the functoriality of \(K\) and \(\otimes\); naturality in \(C\) follows from functoriality of the Postnikov tower in \(HC\).

**Step 6 — Edge maps recover UCT.**  
For \(C=G[0]\) the tower is two‑step, giving a short exact edge sequence
\[
0\ \longrightarrow\ (G\otimes K_*(X))\ \longrightarrow\ K_*(X;G)\ \longrightarrow\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_1(G,K_{*-1}(X))\ \longrightarrow\ 0,
\]
which is exactly the thesis’ **universal coefficient short exact sequence** (with the same non‑splitting caveat). fileciteturn12file14

---

## D. Notes on scope and examples

- **Spaces / spectra.** If \(K(X)=\pi_*(X\wedge E)\) for a spectrum \(E\), then \(K(X;C)\cong \pi_*(X\wedge (E\wedge HC))\); when \(C=G[0]\) this matches the thesis’ \(M(G)\)-smash description of coefficients. fileciteturn12file1 fileciteturn12file3
- **Chain complexes.** Taking \(\mathcal C=D(\mathbb Z)\) and \(K=\mathrm{id}\), the theorem specializes to the classical Künneth spectral sequence for chain complexes, whose \(p\in\{0,1\}\) edge is your displayed short exact sequence (1‑6). fileciteturn12file7
- **\(C^*\)-algebras (topological \(K\)).** In the bootstrap regime the thesis already packages \(K(\,\cdot\,;G)\) as tensoring with a fixed coefficient algebra having \(KU_*(\text{coeff})=(G,0)\), i.e., a monoidal incarnation of the same idea; this slot directly admits derived/twisted variants once one works internally in a stable monoidal envelope. fileciteturn12file17

- **Derived coefficients** \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\) with a **UCT spectral sequence**, not just a short exact sequence.  
- Immediate extension to **twisted** and **parametrized** coefficients by replacing \(HC\) with a local system of \(H\mathbb Z\)-modules in \(\mathcal C\) (your Ch. 7 exactness makes these behave functorially). fileciteturn12file2
- A clean route to **bivariant** versions when \(K\) is represented inside a monoidal stable setting (KK‑flavored contexts), again mirroring your monoidal upgrade.

## 2) Flagship theorem (derived coefficients)

**Derived UCSS (to headline the paper).**  
For exact, colimit‑preserving \(K:\mathcal C\to \mathrm{Mod}_{H\mathbb Z}\) and \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\),
\[
E^2_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\big(H_q(C),\ K_*(X)\big)\ \Longrightarrow\ K_{p+q}(X;C),
\]

**What’s new:** Your UCT short exact sequences (mapping‑cone/‑path construction, presentation‑independence) lift to a **derived universal‑coefficient spectral sequence (UCSS)** in any symmetric monoidal coning/ning setting. Concretely,
\[
E^2_{p,q}\cong \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\bigl(H_q(C),K_*(X)\bigr)\Rightarrow K_{p+q}(X;C),

with the thesis’ UCT as the \(p\in\{0,1\}\) edge when \(C=G[0]\). Your own monoidal upgrade already shows the coefficient functor is *strictly homological*—this is the key input that makes the derived UCSS immediate rather than aspirational. fileciteturn12file7 fileciteturn12file12

That phenomenon, now, is *detected and computable* (as \(d^r\)’s), not an afterthought. fileciteturn12file0

Great question. You **don’t** need to rebuild everything from scratch. Your existing “coefficients via matrix–cone” machinery already extends to bivariant \(K\)-theory once you look at it through the right lens: *let the coefficient object act on one (or both) legs of the bivariant functor via the monoidal product*, and then leverage the known UCT/Künneth tools in bivariant settings. Below is a consolidated plan that is both conceptually tight and computation‑friendly.

---

## 1) Two minimal, equivalent ways to *define* bivariant coefficients

Let \(KK\) denote Kasparov’s bivariant \(K\)-theory on separable \(C^*\)-algebras (replace by your preferred bivariant theory in other contexts), and write \(\boxtimes\) for the exterior product on algebras and \(\otimes\) for the spatial tensor of \(C^*\)-algebras.

Your thesis already yields, for an abelian group \(G\) (or a chain complex \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\)), a **coefficient object** \(\mathcal T(G)\) (resp. \(\mathcal T(C)\)) built from cones of matrix maps and sums, satisfying \(K_*(\mathcal T(G))=(G,0)\) and extending to derived \(C\) by triangles. In the triangulated/monoidal envelope (e.g., the bootstrap KK‑category), you can treat \(\mathcal T(-)\) as an object‑valued functor \(D(\mathbb Z)\to KK\).

**Definition (Right‑leg coefficients).**
\[
KK_*(A,B;\,C)\ :=\ KK_*\!\bigl(A,\ B\otimes \mathcal T(C)\bigr).
\]
**Definition (Left‑leg coefficients).**
\[
{}_C KK_*(A,B)\ :=\ KK_*\!\bigl(A\otimes \mathcal T(C),\ B\bigr).
\]

- Both agree *canonically* whenever \(\mathcal T(C)\) is **rigid/dualizable** in the monoidal KK‑category (e.g., inside the bootstrap class): there is a natural KK‑dual \(\mathbb D\mathcal T(C)\) with
  \[
  KK(A,\,B\otimes \mathcal T(C))\ \simeq\ KK(A\otimes\mathbb D\mathcal T(C),\,B).
  \]
  Thus, you need **no new bivariant gadget** beyond \(\mathcal T(C)\); you only pick on which leg it acts.  
- In practice, fix the right‑leg convention. It plays most nicely with the Rosenberg–Schochet UCT and with Künneth in the second variable.

> **Takeaway.** A *bivariant version* of your construction is primarily a **placement choice** of \(\mathcal T(C)\) on the left or right, not a new theory.

---

## 2) Structure you get “for free” (exactness, products, naturality)

Because \(B\mapsto KK(A,B)\) is homological and \((-\otimes \mathcal T(C))\) is exact and monoidal:

- **Long exact sequences:** triangles in \(B\) or in \(C\) induce long exact sequences in \(KK_*(A,B;C)\).
- **Kasparov product compatibility:** there are canonical pairings
  \[
  KK_i(A,B;C)\ \times\ KK_j(B,D;C)\ \longrightarrow\ KK_{i+j}(A,D;C),
  \]
  obtained by exterior product and associativity in the monoidal category.
- **Functoriality:** covariant in \(B\), contravariant in \(A\), and exact in triangles of \(C\).

None of this requires extra axioms beyond what you already used to make coefficients strict in the monoidal setting.

---

## 3) Computation engine: two spectral sequences that compose

### 3.1 A **derived‑coefficient UCSS** internal to your framework
Your monoidal upgrade shows “with coefficients” is strictly homological. Exactly as in the univariant case, you get:

> **Coefficient UCSS (right‑leg).** For any \(A,B\) and \(C\in D(\mathbb Z)\),
> \[
> E^2_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_p\!\bigl(H_q(C),\ KK_*(A,B)\bigr)\ \Longrightarrow\ KK_{p+q}(A,B;\,C),
> \]
> with naturality in \(A,B,C\) and strong convergence under standard boundedness (e.g., \(C\) bounded below or \(KK(A,B)\) connective/bounded).

- **Edge at \(p=0,1\):** recovers a short exact UCT for \(G\)-coefficients:
  \[
  0\to (G\otimes KK_*(A,B))\ \to\ KK_*(A,B;G)\ \to\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_1\!\bigl(G,KK_{*-1}(A,B)\bigr)\to 0.
  \]
- **Meaningful obstructions:** differentials explain non‑splitting phenomena (now computable), mirroring what your thesis observed in the univariant case.

> *When to prefer this UCSS:* whenever you can access \(KK_*(A,B)\) directly (e.g., via the Rosenberg–Schochet UCT) and you want to turn on derived or torsion coefficients **without** opening up \(K_*(B\otimes\mathcal T(C))\).

### 3.2 A **Grothendieck‑type composition** with the KK‑UCT
In the bootstrap class, the **KK‑UCT** gives
\[
0\ \to\ \mathrm{Ext}^1_{\mathbb Z}\!\bigl(K_{*-1}(A),\,K_*(B)\bigr)\ \to\ KK_*(A,B)\ \to\ \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbb Z}\!\bigl(K_*(A),\,K_*(B)\bigr)\ \to\ 0.
\]
Combine this with your **(univariant) derived UCSS** to compute \(K_*(B\otimes \mathcal T(C))\) from \(K_*(B)\) and \(H_*(C)\), then feed that into KK‑UCT:

> **Composite spectral sequence (practical form).**
> \[
> E^{2}_{p,q}\ \cong\ \mathrm{Ext}^p_{\mathbb Z}\!\Bigl(K_*(A),\ \mathrm{Tor}^{\mathbb Z}_q\!\bigl(H_*(C),\,K_*(B)\bigr)\Bigr)
> \ \Longrightarrow\ KK_{*}(A,B;\,C).
> \]
- This is the computational sweet‑spot in the bootstrap class: it reduces \(KK(A,B;C)\) to Tor/Ext over \(\mathbb Z\) with only the **ordinary** \(K\)-groups of \(A\) and \(B\) and the **homology** of \(C\).

> *When to prefer this composition:* when \(K_*(A)\) and \(K_*(B)\) are known (e.g., graph algebras, AF/AT/AI, rotation algebras) and you want **explicit formulas** or fast collapse criteria.

---

## 4) Collapse and splitting criteria (publishable, checkable)

From either spectral sequence, you get clean, referee‑friendly corollaries:

- If **\(C\) has Tor‑amplitude \(\le 1\)** (e.g., \(C=G[0]\) or two‑term complexes) **or** **\(KK_*(A,B)\)** has projective dimension \(\le 1\), then the UCSS collapses at \(E^2\) and the UCT short exact sequence for \(G\) **splits (unnaturally)**.  
- In the composite sequence, if **\(K_*(A)\)** has projective dimension \(\le 1\) and **\(K_*(B)\)** is flat, then again you get collapse and explicit formulas:
  \[
  KK_*(A,B;C)\ \cong\ \mathrm{Hom}\!\bigl(K_*(A),\,K_*(B)\otimes H_*(C)\bigr)
  \]
  up to the obvious degree bookkeeping; otherwise the first nonzero \(d^r\) is the *unique* obstruction to splitting.

These are strong “value‑add” statements beyond a repackaging.

---

## 5) Twists, equivariance, and “two‑tier” coefficients

- **Twisted bivariant coefficients.** If \(\tau\) is a Picard‑valued twist (line object/local system) in the KK‑category, define
  \[
  KK_*(A,B;\,C,\tau)\ :=\ KK_*\!\bigl(A,\ B\otimes \mathcal T(C)\otimes L_\tau \bigr).
  \]
  All exactness and spectral sequences persist verbatim, now feeding \(K_*^\tau(B)\) into the composite sequence. This is ready‑made for crossed‑products and groupoid algebras in the bootstrap setting.
- **Equivariant \(KK^G\).** Work in \(KK^G\) and insert \(\mathcal T(C)\) in the \(G\)‑equivariant monoidal category. Green–Julg and induction/restriction compatibilities are preserved; you now have \(KK^G_*(A,B;C)\) and an equivariant UCSS.

This is publishable as “twisted/parametrized derived coefficients in bivariant \(K\)-theory.”

---

## 6) Do you ever need a *new* bivariant construction?

Only if you want **balanced coefficients** that **simultaneously** act on *both* legs in a symmetric way *and* you lack dualizability of \(\mathcal T(C)\). Then define a “bi‑coefficient” object \(\mathbb B(C)\) with commuting left/right actions and set
\[
KK_*(A,B;\,C) \ :=\  KK_*\!\bigl(A\otimes \mathbb B(C),\ B\bigr)\ \cong\ KK_*\!\bigl(A,\ B\otimes \mathbb B(C)\bigr),
\]
where the isomorphism is the chosen left–right identification. In the bootstrap category this is overkill because dualizability typically holds at the level you need; but outside it (non‑UCT worlds) a balanced object can be the right abstraction. Even there, you can build \(\mathbb B(C)\) from cones/sums—the same matrix calculus—so it is not an entirely new theory, just a slightly richer *package*.

---

## 7) Concrete “first computations” to include

1) **Graph \(C^*\)-algebras \(E\mapsto C^*(E)\).** These often have \(K_*(B)\) free/finitely generated. For \(C=G[0]\) or two‑term complexes, the composite spectral sequence collapses and
   \[
   KK_*(A,B;C)\ \cong\ \mathrm{Ext}^1\bigl(K_{*-1}(A),K_*(B)\otimes H_*(C)\bigr)\ \oplus\ \mathrm{Hom}\bigl(K_*(A),K_*(B)\otimes H_*(C)\bigr),
   \]
   with easy degree bookkeeping. This is a clean, new calculation channel.

2) **Crossed products \(A\rtimes_\alpha \mathbb Z\).** Combine Pimsner–Voiculescu with the coefficient UCSS to get a two‑layer exact couple computing \(KK_*(A\rtimes\mathbb Z,B;C)\). Showcase a nontrivial differential producing a non‑splitting that your thesis predicted qualitatively.

3) **Mod‑\(n\) and short complexes for AF/AT algebras.** Fast Tor/Ext yields explicit, publishable tables for \(KK_*(A,B;\mathbb Z/n)\) and \(KK_*(A,B;[\mathbb Z\xrightarrow{n}\mathbb Z])\).

---

## 8) Risks and how to keep claims sharp

- **UCT domain.** State clearly when you use the Rosenberg–Schochet UCT (bootstrap class). Outside it, keep to the coefficient UCSS (3.1) which only needs homological exactness and the monoidal action.  
- **Dualizability.** If you assert left/right coefficient equivalence, check dualizability of \(\mathcal T(C)\) in your ambient KK‑subcategory. In bootstrap, build \(\mathcal T(C)\) out of sums/shifts of \(\mathbb C\) and mapping cones—these are dualizable in the thick subcategory generated by \(\mathbb C\).

---

## 9) Executive answers to your two direct questions

**Q:** *What avenues can expand the construction to bivariant \(K\)-theory?*  
**A:** Three, in escalating generality (all feasible now):
1) **Right‑leg action:** \(KK(A,B;C):=KK(A,B\otimes\mathcal T(C))\) with exactness, products, and a coefficient‑UCSS.  
2) **Composite computation:** Pair your derived UCSS for \(K_*(B\otimes\mathcal T(C))\) with the KK‑UCT to get a Grothendieck‑type spectral sequence in Ext∘Tor that collapses in common cases.  
3) **Twisted/equivariant:** Insert twists and \(G\)‑actions; all structures persist.

**Q:** *Do I need a new “bivariant version” of the construction?*  
**A:** **No** for most applications: act with your **existing** coefficient object \(\mathcal T(C)\) on one leg and use the monoidal structure and UCT/UCSS to compute. **Yes** only if you want **balanced** coefficients in non‑dualizable contexts; then you package the same matrix‑cone machinery into a bi‑module object \(\mathbb B(C)\).
